description.narrative: CIVICUS is an international alliance of civil society dedicated to strengthen citizen action and civil society throughout the world, especially in areas where participatory democracy and citizens' freedom of association are challenged. The contribution is part of the Sida/CIVSAM support channelled to the international civil society process surrounding aid effectiveness.

CIVICUS är en internationell CSO - allians med syfte att stärka aktivism och det civila samhället globalt. Insatsen ingår i de Sida/CIVSAM stöd som går till internationella CSOs som stödjer den internationella processen kring civila samhället och biståndseffektivitet.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2013Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Highlights from the year covering 1 January 2013 to 30 June 2013 included: • Publication of the second annual CIVICUS State of Civil Society report (http://socs.civicus.org) which featured over 30 in-depth analyses of the drivers behind changes to the enabling environment and innovative civil society responses, as well as the draft enabling environment index. • Submission of 11 country reports on threats to freedoms of expression, association and assembly, as well as persecution of civil society activists, as part of the Universal Periodic Review process. • Convening of 14 national-level civil society consultations on MDG delivery to-date and the post 2015 agenda to validate and enhance national reports for the Commonwealth Foundation and UN Millennium Campaign Breaking Point initiative. • Emergency advocacy support to 8 civil society actors from around the world for emergency advocacy interventions addressing a diverse array of human rights violations. • Inclusion of CIVICUS inputs in civil society position statements on Sustainable Development Goals and MDGs, meetings related to the International Monetary Fund, World Economic Forum and World Bank, and country recommendations stemming from the UN Human Rights Council Universal Period Review.
Highlights from the year covering 1 July 2013 to 30 June 2014 included:
• Publication of the third annual CIVICUS State of Civil Society report (http://civicus.org/socs2014), which featured contributions from over 30 leading experts on the theme ‘reimagining global governance’ as well as research assessing how well intergovernmental organisations engage civil society. • Implementation of the pilot phase of the Civil Society Index – Rapid Assessment in 6 African countries and consolidation of findings and recommendations in the West Africa Regional Report. • Promotion of 8 multi-stakeholder dialogues initiated by local CSOs around crucial challenges experienced within their communities that engaged more than 400 citizens representing government, civil society, private sector and scientific community. • Launch of the Be the Change website (www.youcanbethechange.com) and Global Day of Citizen Action to celebrate and inspire citizen action, raising awareness about civic space, the importance of it and the need to protect it. • Deepening of our engagement at the UN Human Rights Council including through 10 Universal Periodic Review (UPR) submissions on threats to freedoms of expression, association and assembly, as well as nearly 30 oral statements and over 15 partner led side events to highlight threats to civil society. • Emergency advocacy support to 25 civil society actors and organisations from around the world for emergency advocacy interventions addressing a diverse array of human rights violations. • Hosting an International Civil Society Week with more than 300 civil society actors from around the world participating in 2 major conferences and 6 events. • Enhanced participation of civil society in post 2015 processes through the launch of the Big Development DataShift, Action/2015 and Sustainable Development 2015 initiatives. • Expansion of the CIVICUS alliance by nearly 40% and enhanced global presence, including establishment of offices in New York, Geneva and London.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
